metadata.title: Highly sensitive determination of dopamine by a turn-on fluorescent biosensor based on aptamer labeled carbon dots and nano-graphite

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Title: Highly sensitive determination of dopamine by a turn-on fluorescent biosensor based on aptamer labeled carbon dots and nano-graphite Author: Ling Zhu Guanhong Xu Quan Song Tang Tang Xu Wang Fangdi Wei Qin Hu PII: S0925-4005(16)30378-1 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.snb.2016.03.084 Reference: SNB 19889 To appear in: Sensors and Actuators B Received date: 19-1-2016 Revised date: 18-3-2016 Accepted date: 18-3-2016 Please cite this article as: Ling Zhu, Guanhong Xu, Quan Song, Tang Tang, Xu Wang, Fangdi Wei, Qin Hu, Highly sensitive determination of dopamine by a turn-on fluorescent biosensor based on aptamer labeled carbon dots and nano-graphite, Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.snb.2016.03.084 This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Highly sensitive determination of dopamine by a turn-on fluorescent
biosensor based on aptamer labeled carbon dots and nano-graphite
Ling Zhu, Guanhong Xu, Quan Song, Tang Tang, Xu Wang, Fangdi Wei, Qin Hu
School of Pharmacy, Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing, Jiangsu 211166, PR China
 Corresponding author. Tel./Fax: +86 25 8686 8468. E-mail address: huqin@njmu.edu.cn (Q. Hu)
Graphical abstract

sections.heading: Highlights
sections.text: (1) The preparation of biosensor based on DA aptamer labeled CDs and nan-graphite is simple, rapid and convenient. (2) The biosensor has high sensitivity with a linear range of 0.10-5.00 nM and detection limit of 0.055 nM. (3) The as-prepared biosensor also has good selectivity for specific recognition of dopamine. (4) Sample preparation is very simple just with dilution. (5) All the materials used in the study are low toxic or even nontoxic which avoids environmental pollution.

sections.heading: ABSTRACT
sections.text: In this paper, a novel fluorescent biosensor based on DA aptamer labeled carbon dots (aptamer-CDs) and nano-graphite (NG) for the determination of dopamine (DA) was developed. In this system, aptamer-CDs were in charge of energy donor (fluorophor) and chemical recognition, while NG served as an energy acceptor. In the absence of DA, aptamer-CDs were adsorbed on the surface of NG through π-π stacking and hydrophobic interaction, which led to the fluorescence quenching of aptamer-CDs due to the surface energy transfer. When it was in presence, DA combined with its aptamer anchored on the surface of CDs to form specific globular chain structure which would detach from the surface of NG and thus the fluorescence intensity of aptamer-CDs was recovered. Under the optimal conditions, the fluorescence intensity of aptamer-CDs increased linearly with the increase of DA concentration in the range of 0.10-5.00 nM and the limit of detection was 0.055 nM. This method was successfully applied to the determination of DA in human urine samples with satisfactory results. Keywords: Carbon dots; Dopamine aptamer; Nano-graphite; Dopamine; Fluorescence

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Dopamine (DA) is one of the most important neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and is a precursor of norepinephrine in the biological pathway [1, 2]. It plays an important role in cardiovascular and central nervous system as well as endocrine system [3]. Shortage of DA is correlated with kinds of neurological disorders, such as Alzheimer, schizophrenia and Parkinson’s disease [4, 5]. In clinical practice, the level of DA is detected to help the diagnosis of above diseases. Till now, various analytical methods have been applied to detecting DA including high performance liquid chromatography equipped with fluorescence detector or electrochemical detector [6-9], electrochemical assays [10-12], fluorescent spectrometry [13-15], surface-enhanced raman scattering spectroscopy [16-18]. Among these analytical methods, fluorescence assay using nanoparticles as fluorophores, such as semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) and carbon dots (CDs), has drawn more and more attention for its rapid, simple and convenient operations, and nanoparticles’ excellent optical performances [19-23]. However, the fluorescence assay is limited for the lack of the nanoparticles’ selectivity. In order to overcome this drawback, the introduction of aptamer to the fluorescence assay is one of effective ways [24, 26].
Aptamers are artificial, single-stranded DNA or RNA sequences which are selected in vitro by systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment [26, 27]. They can combine with their homologous targets with high affinity. Based on this property, aptamers have been widely applied to fabricating various biosensors for analyzing of proteins [24, 28-30], metal ions [25, 31], and other small molecules [32, 33].
However, most of the above research was based on turn-off fluorescent probes, which lack high sensitivity due to strong matrix effects. So, a biosensor based on turn-on mechanism is imminently required to improve the sensitivity. In recent years, papers about expanding NG into the system to realize a turn-on mechanism have been reported [27, 34].
Nano-graphite (NG) has recently been considered as a promising energy acceptor based on energy transfer mechanism. As NG is a π-rich nanoparticle which is similar to graphene oxide (GO), it can quench lots of fluorescent materials such as organic dye, QDs and other metal nanoclusters. An excellent donor-acceptor pair can be formed through the strong π-π interaction between NG and CDs [27, 34]. In comparison with GO, NG is cheaper and easier to prepare. Moreover, as a carbon-based nanomaterial, NG shows good biocompatibility and low cytotoxicity which provides great application prospects in wide fields.
In this study, a novel “turn-on” fluorescent biosensor based on DA aptamer labeled CDs (aptamer-CDs) and NG for highly sensitive determination of DA was developed. Wherein, aptamer-CDs served as the fluorophor and DA recognition group, and NG with π-rich structure was used as a superior nanoquencher. In the absence of DA, aptamer-CDs were adsorbed on the surface of NG which led to the fluorescence quenching of aptamer-CDs due to surface energy transfer (SET). When DA was present, it combined with its aptamer on the surface of CDs to form specific globular chain structure which would detach from the surface of NG and thus the fluorescence intensity of aptamer-CDs was recovered. The conditions of preparing and applying
the biosensor were optimized in relevant aspects. Finally, the as-prepared biosensor was successfully applied to the determination of DA in complicated biological fluids. 2. Materials and methods 2.1 Reagents and materials
Citric acid monohydrate, N-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-N-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC), uric acid(UA) and ascorbic acid (AA) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Diethylene triamine and acetone were purchased from Shanghai Lingfeng Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Dopamine aptamer: 5’- NH2-(CH2)6-GTC TCT GTG TGC GCC AGA GAA CAC TGG GGC AGA TAT GGG CCA GCA CAG AAT GAG GCC-3’ was purchased from Shanghai Sangon Biological Engineering Technology & Services Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). The NG (5-15 nm) was purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co., Ltd. (Nanjing, China). Dopamine hydrochloride (DA), L-epinephrine (LEE), L-norepinephrine (NE), 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) and isoprenaline hydrochloride (IPE) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Phosphate buffer saline (PBS, 5mM, pH 7.5). The purified water used in the study was prepared using Direct-Q water purification system (Millipore, USA). All reagents were of analytical grade and without any further purification. 2.2 Apparatus
FT-IR spectra were recorded on a TENSOR 27 spectrometer (Bruker, Germany)
with a resolution of 2 cm -1 and a spectral range of 4000-400 cm -1 .The fluorescence spectra were recorded with an F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer (Hitachi,
Japan). UV-visible absorption spectra were measured with a UV2450 spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan). The transmission electron microscopic and high-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HRTEM) images were acquired on a JEOL JEM-2100 (HR) transmission electron microscopy (Tokyo, Japan). Fluorescence decay curves were performed with a steady state and transient state fluorescence spectrometer (FM-4P-TCSPC, Horiba Jobin Yvon, France). Aptamer combined on the surface of CDs was confirmed by gel electrophoresis (Shanghai Tanon HE-120) in 2.0% agarose gel with 0.5×TBE buffer (pH 8.0) at 80 V for 30 min. 2.3 Preparation of CDs
CDs were synthesised according to a reported method [35]. Briefly, citric acid monohydrate (1.2 g) and diethylene triamine (600 μL) were added into 20 mL of ultrapure water. Then the mixture was transferred to a Teflon equipped stainless steel autoclave (30 mL), which was placed in a drying oven followed by hydrothermal treatment at 200 ℃ for 4h. When cooled down to room temperature, the products were concentrated by rotary evaporation, followed by purification with acetone for three times. The final products were dispersed in ultrapure water as stock solution (8 μg/mL) after vacuum drying. 2.4 Synthesis of DA aptamer labeled CDs conjugates
The conjugates were prepared by well-established carbodiimide chemistry [36, 37]. 30 μL of 1mg/μL EDC in 5 mM PBS was added to 100 μL of CDs solution (8 μg/mL) and the mixture was sonicated for 20 min. Afterwards, 10 μL of the mixture was added to 90 μL of 3.3 μM DA aptamer in 5 mM PBS, and further incubated for 2 h at
25 ℃. 2.5 Determination of DA
The determination of DA was conducted as follow. 50 μL of NG (0.45 mg/mL) was added into 100 μL of aforementioned aptamer-CDs solution to quench the fluorescence, and then the mixture was incubated for 20 min at room temperature. Afterwards, 50 μL of DA standard solution was introduced into the reaction system, and the system was incubated for 1 h at 20℃. The signal output values were calculated according to the relative fluorescence intensity [(F-F0)/F0], in which F and F0 represented the fluorescence intensities of the proposed based biosensor excited at 355 nm in the presence and absence of DA, respectively. It is important to mention that NG suspension should be shaken adequately during the experiment. 2.6 Sample preparation
The urine samples were collected from two healthy volunteers. 0.1 mL of urine was diluted to 6 mL with PBS, and the determination of DA in the urine samples was performed as described in section 2.5.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1 Working principle of the as-prepared biosensor for DA detection
The design strategy of the as-prepared biosensor is shown in Scheme 1. First of all, DA aptamer was modified on the surface of CDs to form a CDs marked biosensor of DA according to the well-established carbodiimide chemistry. In the absence of DA, aptamer-CDs would be adsorbed on the surface of NG via π-π stacking and hydrophobic interaction, the fluorescence of aptamer-CDs was quenched via SET.
When in the presence of DA, DA would combine with the aptamer capped on the surface of CDs to form globular chain structures [38]. The complex would detach from the surface of NG, and the fluorescence intensity of DA aptamer capped CDs recovered significantly. The experiment principle is well identified by fluorescent experimental results shown in Fig. 1.
To investigate the mechanism of the fluorescence quench, related studies were carried out. Fig. 2 showed the fluorescence spectrum of aptamer-CDs (a) and absorption spectra of NG (b), aptamer-CDs (c) and aptamer-CDs mixed with NG (d). As can be seen in Fig. 2a and b, NG had no absorption in the emission wavelength range of aptamer-CDs. The result indicated that quenching of the fluorescence of aptamer-CDs was not caused by inner filter effect. Comparison with Fig. 2c, the absorbance decrease around 350 nm (CDs) after the introduction of NG was attributed to the combination between aptamer-CDs and NG (Fig. 2d). NG could combine with CDs through the strong π-π interaction for its π-rich structure, which partially obstructed excited electrons from the conduction band to the valance band and thus partially quenched the fluorescence of aptamer-CDs [39].
To further reveal the mechanism of fluorescence quenching, time-resolved fluorescence spectra of aptamer-CDs, NG based biosensor before and after adding DA were measured. As shown in Figure 3, the fluorescence lifetime of the aptamer-CDs remained constant with addition of NG and DA, which implied that the fluorescence quenching of aptamer-CDs by NG might be static quenching [40]. 3.2 Characterization of CDs and DA aptamer labeled-CDs
3.2.1 Characterization of CDs
UV-vis absorption (a), excitation (b) and emission (c) spectra were recorded to investigate the optical properties of the as-prepared CDs. As shown in Fig. 4A, the prepared CDs had absorption peaks at 350 nm and 240 nm, respectively. According to the reference [41], the peak at 240 nm is attributed to π-π ＊ transition of aromatic C=C bonds, while the absorption at 350 nm is attributed to n-π ＊ transition of C=O bonds. The maximum excitation wavelength and the maximum emission wavelength of the CDs were recorded to be 355 nm and 437 nm, respectively. A full width at half maximum of the CDs was around 63 nm.
As shown in a typical HRTEM image (Fig. 4B), the as-prepared CDs were well dispersed with a narrow size distribution of 1.5-3.0 nm. The inset in Fig. 4B showed the lattice spacing of 0.19 nm which corresponds to the [102] facet of graphite [42].
Fig. 4C showed the FT-IR spectrum of the CDs. The absorption peaks at 3248 cm -1
and 1558 cm -1 were attributed to the stretching vibration and in-plane bending vibration of -NH, respectively. The characteristic peak around 1658 cm -1 could be attributed to the stretching vibration of C=O. The existence of strong absorption peak of -OH (3418 cm -1 ) indicated that there were still plenty of carboxy groups on the surface of the CDs.
Furthermore, the stability of the CDs was investigated when excited at the maximum excitation wavelength for a long time (Fig. 4D). The fluorescence intensity of the CDs remained nearly no change, which indicated the CDs had good resistance to photobleaching.
3.2.2 Characterization of DA aptamer labeled CDs
The agarose gel electrophoresis result in Fig. 5 showed that DA aptamer labeled CDs moved slower than the pure aptamer due to the increase of mass-to-charge ratio of DA aptamer labeled CDs after modified with CDs. It indicated that DA aptamer was successfully modified on the surface of the CDs. 3.3 Optimization of experimental conditions
The parameters including media pH, aptamer concentration, incubation temperature of the combination between aptamer and CDs, NG concentration, reaction temperature and time of the combination between aptamer-CDs and DA were optimized.
Because CDs are sensitive to pH change, the effect of pH on the fluorescence intensity of CDs was investigated in the range from 1.91 to 9.18 (Fig. S1A). It can be seen that the fluorescence intensity increased with the increase of the pH value in the range of 1.91-6.86, and remained stable while pH was over 6.86. It can be explained that under acidic conditions, the intermolecular hydrogen-bond interaction between amino group and carboxy group on the surface of functionalized CDs would induce CDs agglomeration so that the fluorescence intensity quenched [43]. Hence, the PBS buffer with a pH value of 7.5 was chosen in the work.
Besides, the concentration of aptamer was also studied. As shown in Fig. S1B, the fluorescence intensity of the aptamer-CDs increased with the increasing concentration of the aptamer up to 15 μM, then decreased when the concentration of aptamer was over 15 μM. The reason that the fluorescence intensity increased with aptamer concentration increased (<15 μM) was that aptamer combined with CDs to form an expanded conjugated system,and thus the fluorescence intensity of the system
enhanced. When the concentration of aptamer was excessive (>15 μM) , the fluorescence of the system decreased as the long chain structure of aptamer might block out the fluorescent sites of the biosensor. Thus, 15 μM of the aptamer was chosen as the optimal concentration for the biosensor.
The effect of incubating temperature on the combination between CDs and aptamer was investigated (Fig. S1C). It can be seen that the fluorescent intensity increased with the increase of reaction temperature until 25℃, thus 25℃ was chosen as the optimal incubation temperature for this reaction.
Fig. S1D described the quenching effect with different concentrations of NG. The
fluorescence intensity decreased significantly with the increasing concentration of NG. Whereas the fluorescence intensity cannot be enhanced by the addition of DA when there was too much NG in the system. Therefore, 112.5 μg·mL -1 of NG was chosen as the optimal concentration.
The optimization of reaction temperature for fluorescence recovery by DA is shown in Fig. S1E. The results showed that the reaction accelerated with the increase reaction temperature. Thus, 20℃ was chosen as the optimal incubation temperature as higher temperature would decrease the stability of DA. As shown in Fig. S1F, the fluorescence intensity increased as the reaction proceeded, and then reached a plateau after 30 min. 1 h was chosen as the reaction time for fluorescence recovery. 3.4 Selectivity and interference
Biological matrix due to its complexity may cause interference for the determination of DA. The fluorescent response of the biosensor conducted was investigated against other analogues and other common interferents in urine samples
(Fig. 6). No obvious interfering effects were observed in the presence of 100 nM Pb
2+
and 1 µM of other metal ions (UA, AA, Mg 2+ , Cu 2+ , Fe 3+ , Fe 2+ , Mn 2+ , Ca 2+ , Zn 2+ , K + , Na + ), 5 nM of DA analogues (LEE, NE, 5-HT, IPE) and other interferents (4 mM of glucose and 1µM of urea). It indicated that the as-prepared biosensor possessed outstanding selectivity. 3.5 Method validation
Under the optimal conditions, the fluorescence spectra of the as-prepared biosensor with the addition of different concentrations of DA were studied. As demonstrated in
Fig. 7, the fluorescence intensity of the as-prepared biosensor showed linear increase with the increase of DA concentration in a range of 0.10-5.00 nM. The calibration curve could be expressed by the equation (F-F0)/ F0=0.0638·ln[DA]+0.2192 with the correlation coefficient of 0.9995 (where, F and F0 represented the fluorescence intensities of the biosensor in presence and absence of DA, respectively). The limit of
detection (LOD) was evaluated to be 0.055 nM, which was defined as 3σ/k (Where, σ is the standard deviation of blank measurements (n=10), and k is the slope of calibration graph). As depicted in Table S1, LOD obtained from this method was found to be lower than those of other methods reported. As shown in Table 1, the intra-day and inter-day relative standard deviations (RSDs) of three different concentrations were all within 10%. 3.6 Determination of DA in real samples
To evaluate the feasibility of the proposed method, the as-prepared biosensor was applied to the direct determination of DA by using the standard addition method. The
sample preparation is very simple, just 60-fold-dilution of urine samples. The analytical results are summarized in Table 2. The recoveries were in the range of 90.0-120.0% with RSDs less than 6%.
The results indicated that the precision and accuracy of the method met the needs
of biological sample analysis.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, a novel turn-on fluorescent biosensor based on aptamer labeled CDs and NG was developed for highly sensitive and selective determination of DA. Compared with the reported methods for DA determination, the proposed biosensor has some advantages: (1) The preparation of biosensor based on aptamer-CDs and NG is simple, rapid and convenient. (2) The biosensor has high sensitivity and good selectivity. (3) All the materials used in the study are low toxic or even nontoxic which avoids environmental pollution. The biosensor built can be applied to the determination DA in biological samples with satisfactory results, indicating its promising future in disease diagnosis.
Acknowledgement This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of
China (No. 81173016).

sections.heading: Biographies
sections.text:
Ling Zhu is a graduate student focusing on synthesis and application of carbon dots for M.S. at Nanjing Medical University. She was awarded a B.S. degree in pharmacy from the same university in 2013. Guanhong Xu is an associate professor at School of Pharmacy, Nanjing Medical University. He obtained his M.S. on Medicinal chemistry from Nanjing Medical University in 2009. He has been studying for his Ph.D. at the same university since 2012, where his main research interest is in the synthesis and application of carbon dots. Quan Song is a graduate student focusing on synthesis and application of carbon dots and CdTe quantum dots for M.S. at Nanjing Medical University. He was awarded a B.S. degree in pharmacy from the same university in 2014. Tang Tang is a graduate student focusing on synthesis and application of molecularly imprinted stir bar sorptive extraction technology for M.S. at Nanjing Medical University. She was awarded a B.S. degree in pharmacy from the same university in 2014. Xu Wang is a graduate student focusing on synthesis and application of carbon dots for M.S. at Nanjing Medical University. She was awarded a B.S. degree in pharmacy from the same university in 2014. Fangdi Wei is an associate professor at School of Pharmacy, Nanjing Medical University. She obtained her M.S. on Analytical Chemistry from Nanjing University in 2002. She has been studying for her Ph.D. at Nanjing Medical University since
2009, where her main research interests are in two areas: (1) synthesis and application of surface molecular imprinting polymer and (2) analysis of trace components in life system. Qin Hu is a professor at School of Pharmacy, Nanjing Medical University. She obtained her Ph.D. on Analytical Chemistry from East China Normal University in 2001. She is currently conducting research in two areas: (1) synthesis of nano-silica molecular imprinted polymer and its application in analysis of environmental endocrine disrupting chemicals and (2) molecular imprinted quantum dots application in bioanalysis.

sections.heading: Figure captions
sections.text:
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration of DA detection strategy of aptamer-CDs/NG biosensor.
Fig. 1. Fluorescence emission spectra of aptamer-CDs (a), aptamer-CDs/NG (b) and aptamer-CDs/NG/DA complex (c).
Fig. 2. Fluorescence spectrum of aptamer-CDs (a) and absorption spectra of NG (b), aptamer-CDs (c) and aptamer-CDs/NG (d).
Fig. 3. Time-resolved fluorescence decay curves of aptamer-CDs (a), aptamer-CDs/NG (b) and aptamer-CDs/NG/DA complex (c).
Fig. 4. (A) UV-vis absorption (a), excitation (b) and emission (c) spectra of CDs. Inset shows the photographs of prepared CDs in PBS under visible light (left) and 365 nm UV lamp light (right). (B)TEM images, (C) FT-IR spectrum, (D) fluorescence emission spectrum excited at 355nm of CDs.
Fig. 5. Agarose gel electrophoresis of (a) aptamer-CDs, (b) aptamer.
Fig. 6. Fluorescence intensity changes (F-F0)/F0 of NG-based biosensor in the presence of various potential interferents. Inset: the enlarged area.
Fig. 7. Fluorescence emission spectra of NG-based biosensor in the presence of different concentrations of DA (from a to g: 0, 0.10, 0.20, 0.50, 1.00, 4.00 and 5.00 nM). Inset: calibration plot: fluorescence intensity changes [(F- F0)/F0] versus DA (0-5 nM).

referenceMentions.context: Dopamine (DA) is one of the most important neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and is a precursor of norepinephrine in the biological pathway [1, 2].
Dopamine (DA) is one of the most important neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and is a precursor of norepinephrine in the biological pathway [1, 2].
It plays an important role in cardiovascular and central nervous system as well as endocrine system [3].
Shortage of DA is correlated with kinds of neurological disorders, such as Alzheimer, schizophrenia and Parkinson’s disease [4, 5].
Shortage of DA is correlated with kinds of neurological disorders, such as Alzheimer, schizophrenia and Parkinson’s disease [4, 5].
